The Solar system is actually very spread out. The Sun is literally the biggest object of the Solar system, with the biggest radius, but the planets are more spaced out than that distance. The distances of the planets from the Sun are:
Mercury: 0.4 AU (86 Solar radii)
Venus: 0.7 AU (151 Solar radii)
Earth: 1.0 AU (215 Solar radii)
Mars: 1.5 AU (323 Solar radii)
Asteroid Belt: 2.8 AU (602 Solar radii)
Jupiter: 5.2 AU (1118 Solar radii)
Saturn: 9.6 AU (2064 Solar radii)
Uranus: 19.2 AU (4128 Solar radii)
Neptune: 30 AU (6450 Solar radii)
Kuiper Belt: Further than that

Note: Numbers may not be exact

How can Mercury’s year (88 days) be shorter than Mercury’s day (58 days)? Ok, its because noon to noon on mercury means the planet rotates more than two times per orbit. "Makemake" is pronounced like "mack-air-mack-air"*, not "make make".

It's a polynesian god, so the "silent 'e' at the end, indicating a long vowel earlier in the word" thing from English doesn't apply here.


(* Well, the "e" is a little tricky to explain through English pronunciation, as it's not a standard English sound. But a reasonable approximation is the word "air". Or, if you pronounce the name of the first letter of the English alphabet - "A" - nice and slowly, then you'll notice it consists of two basic sounds ("air-ee"). The first sound is close to the "e" you're looking for.)

What I really like about this channel, as an American, is it's Euro-centric perspective. It makes Europe seem like another place, physically, to the place I inhabit, and my curiosity kicks in and yeah, I want to go there and see things and smell things I have neither seen nor smelled.

I know what British Pounds are, I know how far a kilometer is and what a gram weighs, and I like that you don't dumb that down and show the conversions to dollars, miles and ounces. If I want to know, I can figure it out, and build an organic conversion chart in my head. Which I have done. I like knowing both metric and imperial systems; it makes me feel smart. Although, since I make and fix things for a living, I have two entire sets of tools.

Of course metric is more logical, but we will never (and I mean end-of-the-universe never) lose imperial in the US even though we have incorporated metric into most scientific and technological arenas.

I only have one quibble.  Yes, Pluto was voted down to a Dwarf Planet, but the circumstances of the vote were mired in controversy.
The Astronomical Society's conference where the vote took place only allowed those physically present to vote. Members seeing the conference via streaming were not allowed to vote, thus the vote I was not a true representation (as the majority of those not in attendance would have voted to keep Pluto as a planet), and was thus skewed.
